meanings.definition: A meeting or assembly of the people in early England, especially for judicial or legislative purposes.
meanings.sent1: The folkmote gathered under the ancient oak tree to discuss important matters.
meanings.sent2: The village held a folkmote to decide on new rules for the community.
meanings.sent3: At the folkmote, the villagers argued over who should be in charge of feeding the village cat.
meanings.sent4: The folkmote was a beacon of democracy in the small town, where every voice was heard.
meanings.sent5: The image of the folkmote, with people from all walks of life coming together, stayed with him for years.

meanings.sent1: The mayor will folkmote next week to address the concerns of the townspeople.
meanings.sent2: She decided to folkmote in the town square to discuss the upcoming festival.
meanings.sent3: In a surprising turn of events, the cat attempted to folkmote for more treats.
meanings.sent4: The idea of folkmoting for a fair decision appealed to the entire community.
meanings.sent5: He folkmoted regularly to ensure everyone had a say in the village affairs.
